Bulstrode Whitelockes Annals MTT: Additional Ms 53726
f 80v col T. f 04v col 2*
...
About Allhollantide, seuerall of the principall members of the Societies of
the fower Innes of Court, amongst whom, some were seruants to the king,
had a designe that the Innes of Court should present their seruice to the
king & 0ueen & testify their affections to them, by the outward & splendid
visible [of] testimony, of a Royall Masque of all the 4. societies ioyning
togither, to be by them brought to the Court, as an expression of their loue
& duety to their M$€£৳tyes.
This was hinted att in the Court & by them intimated to the Chiefes of
those societies, that it would be well taken from them, & some held it the
more seasonable, bicause this action would mainest the difference of their
opinion from Mr Prynnes new learning, & serue to confute his Histriomastix
against enterludes.
This designe tooke well, with all the Innes of Court, especially the younger
sort of them, & in order to putt it in execution, the Benchers of each society
mett, & agreed, to haue this solemnity performed, in the noblest & most
stately manner that could be inuented.
The better to effect this, it was resolued, in each house to choose two of
their Members, whom they should iudge fittest, for such a buisnes, to be a
Committee, by ioint assistance to carry on that affayre.
In the middle Temple were chosen of this Committee, Mr Edward Hyde &

Whitelocke, for the Inner Temple S€r Edward Herbert, and Mr Selden. for
Lincolnes Inne M$৳૱£r Atturney Noy, & Mr Gerling, & for Greyes Inne,
S€r lohn Eynch & Mr (blank)
This Committee being impowred by the Benchers of each society, mett
togither, & out of their own number made seuerall subcommittees, one
subcommittee to take care, of the poeticall part of the buisnes, another for
the seuerall properties of the Masquers & Antimas ] quers, & other actors,
another was for the dauncing, & to me in particular was committed, the
whole care & charge of all the Musicke for this Great Masque.
The buisnes being thus distributed, each subcommittee had their meetings,
& carryed on their buisnes, committed to their care, & had monyes prouided,
by an equall proportion, by the Gouernors of each society, who were not
sparing, in that most materiall part, of euery designe & action.
Tmade choyce of Mr Symon lue, an honest & able Musitian, of excellent
skill in his Art, & of Mr Lawes, to Compose the aiers, lessons & songs for the
Masque, & to be the masters of all the musicke under me.
Talso made choice of 4. of the most excellent musitians of the 0ueens
Chappell, Mons€£¥r La Mare, Mons€£¥r Bu Wale, Mons€£¥r Robert, & Mons€£¥r
Mari, and of diuers others of forrein nations, who were most eminent in their
Art, not in the least neglecting any of my own Countrymen, whose knowledge
in Musicke, rendred them usefull in this action, to beare their parts in the
Musicke, which I resolued if T could, to haue so performed, as might excell
any musicke, that euer before this time had bin in England.
Herein I kept my purpose, & for the better preparation & practise of the
Musicke, & that T myselfe might take the better care, & be present with them,
T caused the meetings of all the Musitians, to be frequent att my house in
Salisbury Court, and there T haue had togither att one time, of English, Erench,
ltalian, Germans, & other Masters of Musicke, fourty Lutes, besides other
Instruments, & voyces of the most excellent musitians in consort.
The rest of the subcommittees prepared all things in readyness according to
their seuerall charges, & the Grandees, M$৳૱£r Atturney Generall, Noy, S€r
lohn fynch, S€r Edward Herbert, Mr Selden, & all the rest of the Committees.
tooke great paynes, & neglected no [ meetings for the management of this
great business, of the masque which they knew would be acceptable to their
Master & Mistress & to all the court.
The time for presenting of this masque att Whitehall, was agreed to be
on Candlemas night to end Christmas, & the seuerall parts of it being
brought neer to a readiness for action, Hyde and Whitelocke, were sent by the
Committee, to the Lord Chamberlein, the Earle of Pembroke & Montgomery:
& to S€r Henry Wane the Comtroller of the kings house to aduise with them,

& to take order, about the Sceane, & other matters relating to the Masque,
& about preparing things in the Banquetting house, in order therto, & being
all mett there for that purpose to view to places & to order the matters.
In the debate about them it happened, that there was a difference of opinion
between Sir Henry Wane & Whitelocke, S€r Henry who had as great pride as
parts, and a scornfull slighting way of expressinge himselfe, expected according
to the name of his office, to be Comptroller of all other mens iudgements
& to haue all things done according to his own, & not otherwise, and
appeared to hold himselfe who was a great officer & a priuy Counsellor, to be
undervalued, in a young Lawyers difference of opinion, from his wisdome, &
not att first subscribing to it, and swearing in verbo Magistri if the Comptroller
understood so much Latin
l thought the Socieites whose seruant I was, & in a buisnes acceptable to both
their [M$€£৳tyes] M$€£৳tyes, to be underualued by S€r Henry Wanes not
youchsafing such conveniences & accomodations, as were requisite, & the
place did afforde, for the presenting of their seruices to their M$€£৳tyes att
the Court.
l was befittingly humble to the priuy Counsellor, yett would not sneake, nor
admit of inconveniences, to my Masters, especially uppon this occasion.
Mr Hyde tooke in rowndly with me, & att length by the ] Lord Chamberleins
authority & perswasions interposed, all things were ordered according to our
desires, & we parted, seeming all to be very good friends.
The Gallery behind the state att the end of the banquetting house, was reserved
for the gentlemen of the Innes of Court, who should come thither to see
their masque that there they might sitt togither, & none else to be admitted
with them into that place.
The Bauncers, Masquers Antimasquers, & Musitians did before hand practise
in the place, where they were to present the Masque & the sceanes were
arteficially prepared, att the lower end of the Banquetting house, & all things
were in readyness.
The Grand Masquers were fower gentlemen of each Innes of Court, most
suitable for their persons, dauncing, & garbe for that buisnes, & it was ordered,
that they should be drawne in fower riche Chariotts, 4. Masquers in each
Chariot, by 6 horses in each Chariot.
Butt there grew a difference, about the order of their going, which of the
Innes of Court should haue the first Chariot, & so of the rest in their order,
& how the seuerall grand Masquers should sitt, in the seueral Chariots, who
in the first or chiefest place, & who in the second, third, and last place.

NNS of CouRr 1633.4
To satisfy this it was propounded by Wh€૱£lock£ & assented to by the
Committee, that the Chariots should be made, after the fashion of the
Roman Tryumphant Chariots, & being of an ovall forme in the seats, there
would be no difference of place in them
Eor the seuerall colours, & for the precedence of the Chariots, it was agreed,
that one of each house, of the Committee, should throwe the dice, & as that
happened, the society to be bound of which he that threw was a member.
1 threw the dice for the Middle Temple, & by my cast, had the ] place for the
second Chariot, and siluer & blew for my colours, which colours, Thaue euei
since kept in my liueryes, & uppon all solemne occasions
Candlemas day being come, All the Masquers, Horsemen, Musitians, Bauncers.
& all that were actors in this buisnes, according to order, mett att Ely house
in Holborne, in the afternoone.
There the whole Committee sate all day৳ to order all affayres, and when the
Euening was come, all things being in full readyness, they began to sett forth,
eueryone in their order, towards Whitehall, their way was directed thorough
Chancery lane, and from thence through Temple barre, & so the high way
to Whitehall to the Court.
The first that marched, were twenty footmen in scarlet liueryes, with siluer
lace, each one hauing his sword by his side, a baton in one hand, & a torch
lighted in the other hand, these were the Marshalls men, who cleered the
streets, made way, & were all about the Marshall waiting his commaunds
After them, & sometimes in the midst of them came the Marshall, then Mr
Barrell, afterwards knighted by the king, an extraordinary hansome, proper
gentleman, one of Lincolnes Inne, & was agreed uppon by the Committee
for this seruice.
He was mounted uppon one of the kinge best horses, and richest saddles, and
his owne habit was exceeding rich & glorious, his horsemanship very gallant
& besides his Marshalls men, he had two Lacquayes, who carryed torches by
him, & a page, in liuery, that went by him carrying his cloake.
After him followed one hundred gentlemen of the Innes of Court, fiue &
twenty chosen out of each house, of the most proper & hansome young
gentlemen of the societies
Euery one of them was gallantly mounted, on the best horses, & with the
best furniture, that the Tings stable ] & the stables of all the Noblemen in
Towne, would afforde & they were forward on this occasion, to lend them
to the Innes of Court.
Euery one of these 100 gentlemen, were in very rich clothes, scare anything
butt gould & siluer lace, to be seen of them, & each gentleman, had a Page
22] waiting: sta৲t of col 2on f 0Iv
38] scare: fo৲ scarce
27/ Tinge: fo৲ kinges

& two Lacquays waiting on him, in his liuery, by his horse side, & euery
on had his sword, the Lacquayes carryed torches & the page, the cloake of
his Master.
The richness of their apparell & furniture, glittering by the light of the
multitude of torches attending on them, with the motion & stirring of their
mettled horses, & they many & various gay liueryes of their seruants, butt
especially, the personall beauty & gallantry of the hansome young gentlemen
made the most glorious and splendid show, that euer was beheld in England.
After the horsemen, came the Antimasquers, & as the horsemen had their
musicke, about a dozen of the best Trompets, proper for them, & in their
liuery sounding before them so the first Antimasque, being of Cripples &
Beggars on horseback, had their musicke of keys & tonges, & the like, snapping
& yett playing in a consort before them.
These beggers were also mounted, butt on the poorest leanest iades, that could
be gotten out of the dust cartes, or elsewhere, & the variety & change from
noble musicke, & gallant horses as went before them, unto their proper musicke
& pittifull horses, made both of them the more pleasing.
The habits & properties, of these Cripples & Beggars, were most ingeniously
fitted, (as of all the rest) by the Committees direction, wherin (as in the whole
buisnes) M$৳૱£r Atturney Noy, S€r [ohn Hynch, S€r Edward Herbert, Mr Selden,
those great & eminent persons, as all the rest of the Committee, had often
meetings, & tooke extraordinary care & paynes, in the ordering of this buisnes
& it seemed a pleasure to them.
After the Beggars antimasque came men on Horsebacke play [ ing uppon pipes,
whistles, & instruments, sounding notes like those of birds of all sorts, & in
excellent consort, & were followed by the antimasque of Birds.
This was an owle in an luy bush, with many seuerall sorts of other Birdes,
in a Cluster about the owle gazing as it were uppon her, these were little
boyes, putt into Couers of the shapes of those birdes, rarely fitted, & sitting
on smalle horses, with footmen going by them, hauing all of them torches in
their & the footmen likewise had in the former antimaske, & heer were some
besides to looke unto the children, & this was very pleasant to the beholders.
After this antimasque came other musitians on horsebacke playing uppon
Baggepipes, Hornepipes, & such kind of Northerne musicke speaking the
following antimaske of proiectors, to be of the Scotch & Northern quarters,
& these (as all the rest, had many footemen with torches waiting on them.
first in this Antimasque rode a fellow uppon a little horse with a great Bitt in
his mouth, & uppon the mans head, was a Bitt, with Head stall & raines.
fastened, and signifyed a proiector, who begged a Patent, that none in the

kingdome, might ride their horses, butt with such Bitts, as they should buy
of him.
Then came another fellowe with a bunche of Carretts uppon his head,
& a Capon uppon his fist, describing a proiector, who begged a Patent of
Monopoly, as the first inuenter of the art, to feed Capons fatt with Carrets.
& that none butt himselfe, might make use of that inuention, & haue the
priuiledge for 14 years, according to the Statute
Seuerall other proiectors were in like manner personated, in their antimasque,
& it pleased the spectators the more, because by it, an information was
covertly giuen to the Ting, of the unfittness, & ridiculousness of these
proiects, against the law, & Atturney Noy who had most knowledge of
them, had a great hand in this Antimasque of the Proiectors. /
After this & the rest of the Antimasquers were past, all which are not heer
remembred, there came sixe of the Chiefe Musitians on Horsebacke, uppon
footclothes, & in the Habits of Heathen [pr] priests, & footmen carrying
of torches by them.
After those Musitians followed a large open Chariot, drawne with sixe braue
horses, with large plumes of feathers, on their heads & buttockes, the
Coachman & postilian, in rich antique liueryes, in the Chariot were about
a dozen persons in seuerall habits of the Gods & Goddesses, & by them
many footmen on all sides bearing torches.
After this Chariot followed sixe more of the Musitians on horsebacke with
footclothes habited & attended with torches, as the former were.
After them, came another large open Chariot, like the former, drawne with
six gallant horses, with feathers liueryes & torches as the other had. these
Chariots were made purposely for this occasion, & in this latter Chariot were
about a dozen Musitians in like habit, butt all with some variety, & distinction,
as those in the first Chariot.
These going immediately, next before the Grand Masquers Chariots, played
uppon excellent & lowde musicke, all the way as they went.
After this Chariot came 6 more musitians on footclothe horses, habited &
attended as the other. Then came the first chariot of the Grand Masquers.
which was not so large as those that went before, butt most curiously framed,
carued, & painted, with exquisite art, & purposely for this seruice & occasion.
The forme of it, was after that of the Roman Triumphant Chariots, as neer
as could be gathered by some old prints & pictures extant of them, the seats
in it were made of an ouall forme in the backe end of the Chariot, so that
there was no precedence in them, & the faces of all that sate in it, might be
seen togither.

The Colours of this first Chariot were, siluer & crimson, giuen by [ the lott
to Grayes Inn, (as T remember) the Chariot was all ouer painted richly with
these colours, even the wheeles of it, most artificially layd on, & the carued
worke of it was as curious for that art, & it made a stately show.
lt was drawne with fower horses all on breast, & they were couered to their
heeles all ouer, with cloth of tissue, of the colours of Crimson & siluer, huge
plumes of red and white feathers on their heads & buttockes, the Coachmans
Cap and feather, his long Coate, & his very whippe & cushion, of the same
stuffe & colour.
In this Chariot sate, the 4 Graund Maskers of Grayes Inne, their habits,
doublets, trunke hose & cappes of most riche cloth of tissue, and wrought as
thicke with siluer spangles as they could be placed, large white silke stockins
up to their trunke hose, & rich sprigges in their cappes, themselues proper
& beautifull young gentlemen.
0n each side of the Chariot were fower footmen, in liueryes of the colour of
the Chariot, carrying huge flambois in their hands, which with the torches
gaue such a lustre, to the paintings, spangles & habits, that hardly any [th]
thing could be inuented to appeare more glorious.
After this Chariot came sixe more Musitians, on footclothes & in habits like
the former. These were followed by the second chariot, as the lot fell for the
Middle Temple, this differed not in any thing from the former, butt in colours
only, which were of this Chariot, siluer & blue, it was drawne by my Coach
horses, & driuen by my own Coachman, in the like lieuery of blue & siluer,
& the Chariot & horses couered & decked with cloth of tissue of blue &
siluer, as the former was with siluer & crimson.
In this second Chariot, were the fower Grand masquers of the Middle Temple,
in the same habits as the other Masquers were, & with the like attendance
torches & flambois with the former. After these, followed the third & fowerth
Chariots, & sixe Musitians between each Chariot, habited on footcloth
horses as before, ] the Chariots, were all of the same make, & alike carued
& painted, differing only in the Colours, in the third Chariot rode the Grand
Masquers of the Inner Temple, and in the fourth Chariot went those of
Lincolnes Inne, according to the lot of each of them.
The habits of the 16 Graund Masquers were all the same their persons most
hansome & louely৳ the Equipage so full of state & height of gallantrye, that it
neuer was outdone by any representation mentioned in our former stories.
The Torches & flaming huge flambois, borne by the sides of each Chariot,
made it seem lightsome as att noon day, butt more glittering, & gaue a full
& cleer light to all the streets & windowes as they passed by.

The Marche was slowe, in regard of their great numbers, butt more interrupted
by the Multitude of the spectators, in the streets, besides the windowes, &
they all seemed loth to part with so glorious a spectacle.
This gaue opportunity to Hyde & Whitelocke, who usually were togither, to
take a Coach, & by the other way, to gett before them to Whitehall, where
they found the fayre banquetting house, so crowded with fayre Ladyes,
glistering with their rich clothes, & richer jewells, & with lords & gentlemen
of great quality, that there was scarse roome for the king & 0ueen to enter in.
They saw that all thinges were in readiness there, & the Lo৲$ Chamberlein
carryed them up to the Chamber of the beautifull & ingenious Countess
of Caernaruon his daughter, whose company was no smalle pleasure &
refreshment.
The king & 0ueen stood att a Windowe, looking streight foward into the
street, to see the Masque come by. & being delighted with the Noble brauery
of it, they sent to the Marshall to desire that the whole show, might fetch a
turne about the Tiltyeard, that their M$€£৳tyes might haue a double view of
them, which was done accordingly & then they all alighted att White [ hall
gate, & were conducted to seuerall roomes & places, prepared for them.
The Horsemen of the Masque, and other gentlemen of the Innes of Court,
sate in the Gallery reserued for them, & those of the Committee that were
present, were with them, only Hyde & Whitelocke were placed belowe among
the Grandees, & neare the Sceane, that they might be ready to giue their
assistance, if there should be occasion, & as an extraordinary fauour [th] to
them att that time, & in that presence.
The king & 0ueen, & all their Noble traine, being come in, the Masque
began, & was incomparably performed, in the dauncing speeches, musicke,
& sceanes, the daunces, figures, properties, the voices, instruments, songs,
aiers, composures, the words & actions were all of them exact, & none fayled
in their parts of them, and the sceans were most curious & costly.
The 0ueen did the honor to some of the Masquers to daunce with them
herselfe, & to iudge them, as good dauncers as euer she sawe, & the great
Ladyes were very free & ciuill in dauncing with all the Masquers as they were
taken out by them.
Thus they continued in their sports untill it was almost the morning, & then
the T€₭g & 0ueen, retiring to their chamber, the Masquers & Innes of Court
gentlemen were brought to a stately banquet, & after that was dispersed, euery
one departed to their own quarters.
Thus was this earthly pomp & glory (if not vanity) soone past ouer & gone,
as if it had neuer bin, & as all worldly gories are, but for a moment

Lett it therfore (my children) be your care, to slight these earthly glories, &
not to sett your affections on them, but to seeke after that eternall weight
of glory, which will neuer passe away.
. . .

f 05 col T. f 06 col I*
...
The queen, who was much delighted, with these Solemnities, was so taken with
this show & Masque, that she desired to see it acted ouer againe, wheruppon,
an intimation being giuen to the Lord Maior of London, he inuited the king
& 0ueen & the Innes of Court Masquers, to the Citty, & intertained them,
with all state & magnificence, att Marchant Taylors Hall.
Thither marched, through the Citty, the same show, that went before to
Whitehall, & the same Masque was againe presented to them in the Citty
the same, horsemen, lacquays, liueries, torches, habits, chariots, musicke &
all other parts of the former solemnity, & in the same state & Equipage as
it was before presented.
This also gaue great contentm£₭t to their M$€£৳tyes, & no lesse to the Cittizens,
especially to those of the younger sort, & of the female sexe, & it was to the
great honour, & no lesse charge of the Lo৲d Maior freeman.
After these dreames past, & these pompes vanished, the Committee of the
Masque, required an account, of all the disbursements, & all men were
satisfyed justly & bountifully.
for the musicke, which was perticularly committed to my charge, T gaue to
Mr lues, & to Mr Lawes 100 I. a piece, for their rewards, for the 4 french
gentlemen, the 0ueens seruants, I thought that a hansome & liberall gratifying
of them, would be made knowne to the 0ueen, their Mistris, and well taken
by her.
T therfore inuited them one morning, to a Collation att St Bunstans Tauerne,
in the great Roome, the oracle of Apollo, where each of them had his plate
layd ] for him, couered, & the Napkin tyd, & when they opened their plates
they found in each of them, forty pieces of gould, of their Masters coyne, for
the first dish, & they had cause to be much pleased with this surprisall.
The rest of the Musitians, had rewards answearable to their parts, & qualities,
& the whole charge of the Musicke, came to about one thousand pownds.
The clothes of the Horsemen, & the liueries of their pages and lacquays.
which were att their owne perticular charge, were reckoned one with another
att 100 I. a suit, att the least, & one hundred of those suits, to amount
unto 10000 I.

The Charges of all the rest of the Masque, & matters belonging to it, were
reckoned att as much more, & so the charge of the whole Masque, which
was borne, by the societies, & by the perticular members of it, was accounted
to be aboue twenty thousand pownds.
Twas so conuersant with the Musitians, & so willing to gaine their fauour,
especially att this time, that I composed an aier my selfe, with the assistance
of Mr lue, and called it, Whitelockes Coranto, which being cryed up, was
first played publiquely, by the Blackefryars musicke, who were then esteemed
the best common Musicke in all London.
Whensoeuer I came to that house, (as T did sometimes in those dayes) though
not often) to see a play৳ the Musitians would presently play Whitelockes
Coranto, & it was so often called for, that they would haue it played, twice
or thrice in an afternoone.
The 0ueen hearing it, would not be perswaded, that it was made by an
Englishman, bicause she said, it was fuller of life & spirit then the English
aiers use to be, butt she honourd the Coranto & the maker of it with her
M$€£৳tyes royall commendation. ]
lt grew to that request, that all the Common Musitians in this Towne, & all
ouer the Tingdome, gott the composition of it, & played it publiquely in
all places, for aboue thirty years after, Butt T had need to make some excuse,
for spending my time, then, & now about so light a buisnes as this Coranto
was, T shall giue the reasons of it...
. . .

f 07 col T. f 07y col 1
. . .
A little while after the Masque was performed, the Committee ordered S€r
lohn Eynch, Mr Gerling, Mr Hyde & Whitelocke, to attend the king &
0ueen & in the name of the 4 Innes of Court, to returne their humble
thankes, for their M$€£৳tyes gratious acceptance of the tender of their seruice
in the late Masque.
They were first brought to the king, who gaue to all of them his hand to kisse,
then S€r lohn Eynch, in the name of the rest spake to the king to this effect.
S€r. By commaund of your M$€£৳tyes most affectionate, and loyall subiects,
the Readers & gentlemen of the 4 Innes of Court, we are heer to attend you,
with their most humble thankes, for your great fauour to them, in your
gratious acceptance, of the tender of their seruice & affections to your M$€£৳ty
in the late Masque presented to you, & for vouchsafing your royall presence
att it.

The king, with great affability & pleasingness, answeared him presently
to this purpose.
Gentlemen. I pray assure those from whom you come, that we are
exceeding well pleased with that testimony which they lately gaue us, of
their great respect & affection to us, which was very acceptable & performed
with that gallantry, & in so excellent a manner, that I cannot butt giue
them thankes for it, & shall be ready upon all occasions to manifest the
good opinion ] T haue of them, & to doe them & you in perticular,
any fauour.
from the king, we were brought to the 0ueen, & kissed her hand, &
S€r lohn Eynch her Atturney hauing made the like complement to her
M$€£৳ty, she answeared, quicke, & well pleased.
That she neuer sawe any Masque more noble, nor better performed then
this was, which she tooke as a perticular respect to her selfe, as well as to
the king, her husband, & desired that her thankes might be returned to
the Gentlemen for it.
This being reported to the Benchers, of each society, they gaue thankes
to their respective members, that were of the Committee, for the honour
they had done to the society, by the well ordering of that buisness of
the Masque.
